This is a '''list of all books, films and media produced so far in ''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]'''''. == Books == The books can either be listed in the order in which the stories first appeared in newspapers or magazines (the "production order"), or in the order they were first published in album form ("publication order"). As many early stories were altered in the redrawings, and therefore chronologically fit in more with the later albums, both orders can be considered valid. Sometimes the redrawings introduced problems with the chronological order, one example is when Sheik Patrash Pasha presents a copy of ''Destination Moon'' in ''Cigars of the Pharaoh'' — ''Destination Moon'' was published almost 20 years after ''Cigars of the Pharaoh''. === Production order === # ''[[Tintin in the Land of the Soviets]]'' - 2004 ([[Egmont Publishing|Egmont]]) |} == Radio == The [[BBC]] produced two series of Tintin radio dramatisations by Simon Eastwood. They were first broadcast on [[BBC Radio 5 (former)|BBC Radio 5]] in 1992 and 1993. The cast featured [[Leo McKern]] as Captain Haddock ([[Lionel Jeffries]] in series 2), [[Andrew Sachs]] as Snowy, [[Stephen Moore (actor)|Stephen Moore]] as Professor Calculus, [[Charles Kay]] as the Thompson twins, and [[Richard Pearce (British actor)|Richard Pearce]] as Tintin. Both series were released on BBC Audio Cassette (ISBN 0-8072-8103-4) === Series one === # [[The Black Island]] # [[The Secret of the Unicorn]] # [[Red Rackham's Treasure]] # [[Destination Moon]] # [[Explorers on the Moon]] # [[Tintin in Tibet]] === Series two === # [[The Seven Crystal Balls]] # [[Prisoners of the Sun]] # [[The Calculus Affair]] (in two parts) # [[The Red Sea Sharks]] (in two parts) === Specials === # [[The Castafiore Emerald]] (double-length Christmas special). It guest-starred [[Miriam Margolyes]] as [[Bianca Castafiore]]. It has not yet received a commercial release nor a repeat broadcast. == Films == There have been a number of films featuring the characters, but not always based on original works by HergÃ©. There have been two [[live action]] films with actors cast for their resemblance to the characters. *''[[The Crab with the Golden Claws (film)|The Crab with the Golden Claws]]'' (''Le Crabe aux pinces d'or'') (1947, [[animation]], [[Film adaptation|adaptation]]) *''[[Tintin and the Golden Fleece]]'' (''Tintin et le mystÃ¨re de la Toison d'or'') (1961, [[live action]], original story) *''[[Tintin and the Blue Oranges]]'' (''Tintin et les oranges bleues'') (1964, live action, original story) *''[[Tintin and the Temple of the Sun]]'' (''Tintin et le temple du Soleil'') (1969, animation, [[Film adaptation|adaptation]]) * ''Tintin et la SGM'' (1970), animated promotional short film by [[Belvision]]. *''[[Tintin and the Lake of Sharks]]'' (''Tintin et le lac aux requins'') (1972, animation, original story) *''[[I, Tintin]]'' (''Moi, Tintin'') (1966, [[Documentary film|documentary]]) *''[[Tintin and I]]'' (''Tintin et Moi'') (2003, documentary) (about Georges Remi, better known as [[HergÃ©]], and his creation [[Tintin (character)|Tintin]]) *''[[The Adventures of Tintin: Secret of the Unicorn]]'' (2011) a [[motion capture]] film directed by [[Steven Spielberg]] and produced by [[Peter Jackson]]. == Television == There have been two [[Animation|animated]] [[television series]], based on the [[comic books]]. * ''[[HergÃ©'s Adventures of Tintin]]'' (1958 – 1962), was produced by [[Belvision Studios|Belvision]] (Belgium). * ''[[The Adventures of Tintin (TV series)|The Adventures of Tintin]]'' (1991 – 1992), was produced by [[Ellipse Programme|Ellipse]] (France), and [[Nelvana Limited|Nelvana]] (Canada). == Stage shows == *''[[Tintin in India - The Mystery of the Blue Diamond]]'', written by [[HergÃ©]] and [[Jacques van Melkebeke]], was performed in 1941. *''[[Kuifje - De Zonnetempel (De Musical)|Kuifje - De Zonnetempel]]'', also released as ''[[Tintin - Le Temple du Soleil - Le Spectacle Musical|Tintin - Le Temple du Soleil]]''. The books ''[[The Seven Crystal Balls]] and [[Prisoners of the Sun]]'' were adapted as a Dutch [[Musical theater|musical]] stage show in 2001 by [[Dirk BrossÃ©]] and [[Seth Gaaikema]]. The show was adapted a year later by [[Didier van Cauwelaert]] as a French production. *''Tintin the show'' - Barbican Theatre - produced by The Young Vic Theatre Company. Performed for the first time on Thursday 1 December 2005. It was based on the book ''[[Tintin in Tibet]]'' and due to the 2007 HergÃ© centenary it was decided that it would return in late 2006. == Video games == So far four Tintin video games have been released: #[[Tintin on the Moon]] (1989). #[[Tintin in Tibet (video game)|Tintin in Tibet]] (1996). #[[Prisoners of the Sun (video game)|Prisoners of the Sun]] (1997). #[[Destination Adventure]] (2001). #[[The Adventures of Tintin: The Game]] (2011). == Reprints and republications == * In 1951 British weekly comic ''[[Eagle (comic)|The Eagle]]'' ran "King Ottokar's Sceptre" * In the 1960s and 1970s, various Tintin comics were reprinted in the American children's magazine ''[[Children's Digest]]''. * In 2000â2001, the short-lived magazine "Explore!" ran "The Black Island" and "King Ottokar's Sceptre" == Other books == {{For|a detailed list of unofficial works|List of Tintin parodies and pastiches}} {{For|a list of books that discuss the series and its author|List of books about Tintin}} * In 1983, [[Benoit Peeters]] published ''Le monde d'HergÃ©'' (later translated in [[English language|English]] as ''[[Tintin and the World of HergÃ©]]''), which chronicles the illustrated history of [[Belgium|Belgian]] writer-artist Georges Remi (better known as [[HergÃ©]]), and his creation ''Tintin''. * In 1993, after the death of HergÃ©, his friend [[Frederic Tuten]] published ''Tintin in the New World: A Romance'' (ISBN 0-7493-9610-5). More a [[thought experiment]] than a new adventure, Tintin here grows up: he is seduced and falls in love, has a dream about the death of Snowy and caring for an invalid Haddock, and critically examines his life and experiences. * In 1980, a pirate comic/parody, ''[[The Adventures of Tintin: Breaking Free]]'', was released, featuring Tintin as an unemployed youngster living with his uncle-by-marriage Haddock, who gets involved with the [[socialist]]/[[anarchists]]. * In December 1999, a pirate comic book ''[[Tintin in Thailand]]'' came into circulation. The book, illustrated by Thai artists{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}, presented Tintin, Haddock and Calculus on a sex holiday to [[Bangkok]], with numerous allusions to the characters being unhappy with their treatment by the HergÃ© Foundation. In 2001, Belgian police made several arrests regarding the book in the Belgian town of [[Tournai]]. * ''[[The Adventures of Tintin at Sea]]'' by Michael Farr (2004) ISBN 0-7195-6119-1 - a guide to the nautical-related scenes in canonical Tintin books == See also == * [[List of films based on French-language comics]] == Notes == {{reflist|2}} {{Tintin and HergÃ©}} [[Category:Tintin|Books, films, and media]] [[id:Buku, film dan media Tintin]] [[si:à¶§à·à¶±à·à¶§à·à¶±à· à¶´à·à¶­à·, à¶ à·à¶­à·âà¶»à¶´à¶§ à·à· à¶¸à·à¶°à·âà¶º]]
